Who / What: Large communities from Apple, PatientsLikeMe, Wikipedia
Use case: Produce intellectual property or curate knowledge
Description: Can communities create and store technical knowledge? Online communities are one of the largest emerging social phenomena of the last quarter-century. Apple is one of the most prominent nodes, and the algorithms of both Facebook and YouTube exercise significant control on how those communities behave. Communities provide creativity and additional resources that are typically not accessible by normal hierarchical organization. But they’re harder to set up and direct.

Use case: Cross sell of financial products across siloed product groups through "invisible" network employees
Description: A cohort of mid-tier employees was instrumental in the cross-selling of financial products in an investment banking firm, by enabling smaller transactions across different (and otherwise siloed) product groups and effectively serving as integrators across org chart divides. Without dedicated support and recognition, many of these valuable staff members were leaving the firm. Once their role was highlighted, incentives and support structure were put in place and the overall organization benefited.

At the intersection of academia’s invention and funded innovation at scale, is Europe-centered Crowdhelix – “that forges links between an international network of excellent researchers and innovating companies, so that they can plan and deliver pioneering collaborative projects."

Use case: Improve access to qualified gig workers
Description: Mindsumo crowdsources work to university students.

A.team provides access to a marketplace of talented freelancers, but goes one step beyond the traditional approach of companies like Fiverr or Upwork: it assembles teams, able to perform more complex and innovative work than the typical gig that other platforms enable.
One of the first and most established contractor marketplaces
Quantopian's contests, populated by thousands of “quants” from various fields, aim at creating new, and radically diverse, financial markets trading algorithms.

Web3 technology offer great promise for the engagement of skilled communities such as developers. But the technical requirements to build such infrastructure can be daunting. Companies like Lens Protocol try to simplify the composability of community-engagement mechanism, by building specialized modules for connection and incentivization.

Apple AppStore's creates incentives and standards for developers, hence generating emergent optimization dynamics that result in competitive strength. Apple only touches the system's "high-leverage" points (e.g. policies, security, payment, performance), and the system then largely optimizes itself.

Microsoft has established a strong market "ecosystem" through its technical and commercial platform for developers who use their products. They support the commercialization thanks to the cross-selling those developers can do on the back of Microsoft's market presence. They also control some important high-leverage points of the system, such as security and policies standards to help with trust and control, and collaboration through GitHub. They also support the cybersecurity layer. The result is an emerging, intelligent adaptation of the network.

Amazon has established a strong market "ecosystem" that leverages its supply chain platform, arguably one of the most sophisticated and commercially powerful in the world. They control some high-leverage points in the system, such as pricing, client engagement, logistics policies. The result is emerging network intelligence whose outcomes are continuous adaptation and, so far, market success.

Use case: Create network effect for consumers and e-commerce
Description: Tencent's subsidiaries have created significant network dynamics across connecting people, giving them incentives to collaborate, and providing an environment where it is safe (or at least it is perceived to be safe, within sometime-politicized boundaries) to do so.

Can a market structure help an enterprise make internal decisions? China’s white-goods manufacturer Haier has radically re-thought its organizational structures to do that. Haier created tension between internal units, reducing their default bias to work with each other. For instance, individual-market supply chains, marketing, and sales groups are free to buy external services if they don’t feel their internal colleagues' offers are good enough.

Use case: Generate more and better innovation ideas
Description: General innovation
Ubuntoo is a Service provider that brings together experts and knowledge, focused on environmental sustainability innovation.

Use case: Collaborate around community based biology in large networks
Description: Including synthetic biology, the operating model is more the one of a movement than a traditional academic collaboration. Supported by MITMediaLab

Use case: Deliver a vision for the future, centered around art, and culminating in one-week festival
Description: The yearly Burning Man festival is organized by Black Rock City Limited Liability Company, which uses similar models for other activities. The festival today congregates 70,000 people and has been running since 1986. People build and then completely dismantle a temporary city in the desert, including its infrastructure, security, food and shelter – respecting a strict “leave no trace” credo inspired by sustainable-development ideals. It is a great demonstration of how agilely coordinated bottoms-up activities can deliver complex systems at scale. Burning Man’s experience is portable for instance to urban planners, refugee camps, and generally city planning.

Use case: Answer coding questios and share knowledge
Description: StackOverflow is an independent, open community for anyone that codes, with the joint objective to get answers to the toughest coding questions, share knowledge with coworkers in private (and find a job, which acts as a powerful motivator). Other software vendors have been collaboration communities for many years, such as SAP Community Network.

There are some experimental examples of platforms intended to create radically new organizational structures, whereby people work on the tasks that they like and they’re competent for, and they get fairly rewarded for it. They borrow some of the concepts of holocracy (used for instance at retailer Zappos, software firm Satalia, or to an extent videogames producer Valve).
The Openinsulin.org is “working to develop the first practical, small-scale, community-centered model for insulin production to make insulin accessible to all”.

labDAO members could build data and resource management software, in return for token ownership. The DAO interacts with physical labs (existing or new) by paying to run experiments and providing data or materials to the token holders who funded the work. Data can be managed in an electronic lab notebook (ELN) on chain, using NFT datasets, for later licensing or use by third parties. New labs can join the DAO to earn tokens for their services or to support scientific progress by providing their methods at cost. Source: arye.substack.com/p/building-a-labdao-for-web3-biotech

Repl.it strives to democratize coding by providing easier access to all components of the software development stack, as well as facilitating the collaboration between people through collaborative editing. Its collaboration and incentives enable collective contributions.

Use case: Use Web3 for distributed machine learning processing
Description: Sentient network attempts to build a distributed global computer with the participant nodes providing a portion of their hardware resources for artificial intelligence computations. Each node will determine what allocation of its resources it wishes to make available to the network for computations, and receive the corresponding rewards. Status as of 2022 was unclear

Use case: Make nature-based climate credits more trustworthy
Description: Digital Gaia focuses on verifiability of nature-based solutions for climate offsets. It augments the power of a community of contributors (carbon offset project developers, data providers, data engineers) and integrates real world data with natural models to continuously evaluate regenerative project’s real global impact–from proposal to execution. It does so by using Web3 blockchain technology. It is inspired by the work of renown neuroscientist Karl Friston on active inference and minimization of free energy to optimize predictions.

Use case: Connect science to funding in a decentralized manner
Description: Molecule is creating collaborative ecosystems, where stakeholders in drug development can work together to expedite the process of bringing novel therapeutics to patients. They are connecting leading researchers to funding by turning intellectual property and its development into a liquid and easily investable asset.

Can ecosystems decide? Ecosystems benefit from the natural experiments that happen in loosely connected parts of the network and can provide significant creativity as well as resiliency. They’re however harder to align and control. Nature effectively chooses, over time, based on alternatives created by mutations of genes and the environment; it expresses those genes in the short term through epigenetics (for instance metabolic changes in response to a famine, transmitted to the next generation); and mutations of RNA seem to show longer-term "memory" of the reaction to biological event (such as in the case of mounting a defense to a bacteria)

Can hierarchies sense environmental changes? Hierarchical structures are fast and efficient. But they struggle to sense fast-changing environments and are poor at harnessing everyone’s intelligence. Note the Chinese authorities’ slow response and lack of transparency in the crucial inception weeks of the Coronavirus infection in Wuhan, then followed by swift removal of civil liberties to control the spread.

Use case: Nurture communities of experts that complement in-house customer interaction teams
Description: Nurture communities of experts that complement your in-house customer interaction teams. Use deep semantic analysis to understand trends. Ensure that product management teams are connected in a bi-directional way so that they can learn from new queries and help create knowledge artifacts to feed the distributed problem solvers.

Community with large number of quantitatively skilled analysts enabling crowdsourced data science, running competitions. Closed in 2020, and assets were transferred to low-fee financial trading platform Robinhood.

Hyperconnectivity and the ability to inventory and quality-control millions of people at minimal marginal cost has changed its dynamics radically, effectively surfacing the cognitive surplus of millions of people and reshaping many jobs. Platforms have in many respects created the current “gig economy” movement, and they increasingly show specialization of roles where very specific expertise is harnessed in a way that wasn’t possible before – an idea first publicized by MIT’s Malone and colleagues in 2011

Use case: Use eSports and Multiplayer video games to attract millions
Description: Better network connectivity and faster processors have led to the emergence of massive global networks of players, part of them becoming professionals and influencers who tap into actual and lucrative markets. League of Legends is an example. The dynamics of the games, including novel strategies, are integral part of the entertainment, the training of the respective AI, and the future development of the games

Use case: Barter time in a peer to peer marketplace
Description: Experts barter time and are matched to requests for help related to their area of expertise. Time is used as a currency.
The AirBnB of cars, where participants give their car to qualified users, and get paid for the use of their assets during its downtime. Possibly extensible to other forms of transportation.

Use case: Use data science competitions for social impact
Description: DrivenData is a social enterprise dedicated to bringing the data tools and methods that are transforming industry to the world's biggest challenges. As part of that work, the DrivenData competition platform channels the skills and passion of data scientists, researchers, and other quantitative experts to build solutions for social good. These online machine learning challenges are designed to engage a large expert community, connect participants with real-world data problems, and highlight their best solutions.

Use case: Provide a platform for social-impact crowdsourcing innovation
Description: HeroX is a platform and open marketplace for crowdsourcing innovation and human ingenuity, co-founded in 2013 by serial entrepreneur, Christian Cotichini and XPRIZE Founder and Futurist, Peter Diamandis. HeroX offers a turnkey, easy-to-use platform that supports anyone, anywhere, to solve everyday business and world challenges using the power of the crowd. Uniquely positioned as the Social Network for Innovation, HeroX is positioned as "the only place you can build, grow and curate your very own crowd."

Joro.app helps consumer track their personal carbon footprint by translating purchases data (from an API) into carbon tonnes equivalent. The app also has a community component, connecting users with sustainability challenges, classes and other educational tools, along with a social network to communicate with peers to track relative progress (Source: TechCrunch).

Decentralized.science provides a public repository of Open Peer Reviews and a reviewers’ reputation network, and uses blockchain to maintain records. Decentralized science rewards good and fast peer reviews to increase the quality and productivity of academic research
